review.title: Bootstrapping Ternary Relation Extractors
review.abstract: Binary relation extraction methods have been widely studied in recent years. However, few methods have been developed for higher n-ary relation extraction. One limiting factor is the effort required to generate training data. For binary relations, one only has to provide a few dozen pairs of entities per relation, as training data. For ternary relations (n=3), each training instance is a triplet of entities, placing a greater cognitive load on people. For example, many people know that Google acquired Youtube but not the dollar amount or the date of the acquisition and many people know that Hillary Clinton is married to Bill Clinton by not the location or date of their wedding. This makes higher n-nary training data generation a time consuming exercise in searching the Web. We present a resource for training ternary relation extractors. This was generated using a minimally supervised yet effective approach. We present statistics on the size and the quality of the dataset.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: Knowledge databases (KBs) such as DBPedia (Auer et al., 2007), YAGO (Suchanek et al., 2007), Freebase (Bollacker et al., 2008) and NELL (Mitchell et al., 2015), as well as Open IE tools and resources such as Reverb (Fader et al., 2011b) and Ollie (Mausam et al., 2012) contain many millions of binary relationship cases that can be used for remote extraction of binary relationships. However, these knowledge databases are very poor when it comes to ternary relationships. In contrast, we provide a resource that can be used directly to encourage and promote more research on reading and extracting binary relationships. A number of papers have examined the temporal scoping of facts by adding a temporal dimension to facts (Wang et al, 2010; jaya, for example, extending this relationship to a generative one).

sections.heading: 3 Data Generation
sections.text: In this section we present our method for generating ternary relationships and their instances.

sections.heading: 3.1 Input
sections.text: Our method automatically learns many different ternary relationships that are relevant to each type of event. There are two advantages to specifying event types of interest rather than thinking directly in terms of ternary relationships. First, a broad event type can capture many relevant ternary relationships that naturally occur in the data. Second, specifying an event type requires much less human effort than manually specifying a list of all conceivable ternary relationships, some of which may not be present in the data. Table 1 shows the event types covered in our resource. For each event type, we specified a maximum of three trigger verbs indicating a potential mention of the event type. We will later describe how event verbs are automatically extended in an iterative manner. This is similar to the expansion of seed instances or pattern suchants (2011, Mitchell et al; asek, 2009; al; al).

sections.heading: 3.2 Candidate Template Generation
sections.text: Once we have defined event types with their trigger verbs, we can create ternary relationships for each event type > net types > net types, and the first step is to create ternary relationship templates. An example template is: < person > endorses < politician > for < political office >. We create these templates directly from the data. We do this by first analyzing the raw corpus and extracting 5-item sequences from the form: N1, V, N2, P, N3; where the Ns are noun phrases, V is a verb, so that V is a trigger verb of an event, and P is a preposition. We create templates from 5-item sequences as follows: we replace each noun phrase N1-N3 with its semantic type. Specifically, we look for entity types in two types of semantic types, P is a trigger verb of an event and P is a preposition. We create templates from 5-item sequences as follows: we replace each noun phrase N1-N3 with its semantic type, V is a verb of noun phrases, P is a verb of a verb, and P is a preposition.

sections.heading: 3.3 Template Filtering
sections.text: To do this, we manually filter out any templates that do not have useful external relationships for that particular topic. < NEL Person > killed < NEL Person > with < WDN Weapon > labels each template manually with descriptive labels for the appropriate placeholders of the noun phrase. < NEL Person > with < WDN Weapon > is labeled with MurderEventMurderer, MurderEventMurdered, MurderEventMurdered, MurderEventInstrument. Each triple label is considered to be a single external relationship. Therefore, we have the ternary relationship Murderer Murdered Instrument. Such an external relationship would have instances like Bob, Alice, Messer, indicating that Bob murdered Alice with a knife. We get instances of templates and hence external relationships by maintaining the supporting 5-item sequences of each of the accepted templates.

sections.heading: 3.4 Iterative Template Generation
sections.text: To increase the size of the resource, we increase the number of trigger verbs per event type. This is done automatically. First, we extract 5-item sequences of the form N1, V, N2, AP, N3 from the raw data. Second, we no longer limit the phrase between N2 and N3 to prepositional phrases, P is now AP = each phrase. We limit the length of AP to a maximum of three words. Then, we find 5-item sequences in which all three arguments N1 − 3 match the arguments of an instance of a template in Section 3.3. Therefore, we use the previously created instances as remote supervision to detect new templates. All new (V, AP) pairs that form candidate templates that occur with more than 10 different instances of an existing template trigger the new templates, which we do not support overlapping with the introduction of the required minimum templates 3.

sections.heading: 4 Evaluation
sections.text: We applied our data generation process to Wikipedia (WKP) and the ClueWeb09 (CWB) corpus. We first generated a set of candidate templates from Wikipedia using the method described in Section 3.2. We did not apply this step to the ClueWeb corpus as it can be noisy. We then manually filtered the generated candidate templates as described in Section 3.3. This is iteration 0. We had a total of 186 templates in iteration 0 and 50 ternary relationships across 18 event types. The number of templates increases across iterations, so we get more templates in subsequent iterations that can be used to populate our 50 ternary relations.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we address the bottleneck that has slowed down research on extracting higher n-relations. To this end, we have generated a training data resource for ternary relationship extractors. We described a method for learning and colonizing ternary relationships initially only using prepositional, phrase-based templates. In addition, our method also learns templates that are not based on prepositions in an iterative manner. We hope that this resource will foster research into ternary relationship extraction.
